titleStmt.title: Great victories obtained by the Earle of Denbigh at Shrewsbury, Chulmely, aud [sic] other parts in Cheshire. Where were taken prisoners. The Lord Newports sonne, Lieutenant Colonell Horton, Serjeant Major Manly governour of Banger, Sergeant Major Fisher, 1 lieutenant colonells colours, and others. 100 armes. 2 barrels of powder and store of bullets. 66 prisoners more, amongst which some others of note, good horse, and other purchase. Sergeant Major Pinkney slain on our side, and 5 or 6 wounded. With the copie of the oath that was imposed on the cavaliers before the garrison was taken. Published according to order.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 11 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Great victories obtained by the Earle of Denbigh at Shrewsbury, Chulmely, aud [sic] other parts in Cheshire. Where were taken prisoners. The Lord Newports sonne, Lieutenant Colonell Horton, Serjeant Major Manly governour of Banger, Sergeant Major Fisher, 1 lieutenant colonells colours, and others. 100 armes. 2 barrels of powder and store of bullets. 66 prisoners more, amongst which some others of note, good horse, and other purchase. Sergeant Major Pinkney slain on our side, and 5 or 6 wounded. With the copie of the oath that was imposed on the cavaliers before the garrison was taken. Published according to order.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Denbigh, Basil Feilding, -- Earl of, ca. 1608-1675 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: GREAT VICTORIES Obtained by the Earle of Denbigh at Shrewsbury, Chulmely, and other parts in Che≈øhire.

list.item: Serjeant Major Manly Governour of Banger,
2 Barrels of powder and ≈øtore of bullets.
66 Pri≈øoners more, among≈øt which ≈øome others of note, good hor≈øe, and other purcha≈øe.
Serjeant Major Pinkney ≈ølain on our ≈øide, and 5 or 6 wounded.

p.hi: With the copie of the Oath that was impo≈øed on the Cavaliers before the Garri≈øon was taken.

div.p: London, printed by J. Coe, Anno Dom. MDCXLIV.

div.head: A LETTER FROM An eminent Commander in the Earle of Denbighes Quarters.

body.p:
SInce my la≈øt, the me≈ø≈øenger whereof is pi≈øtold by the way with my Lords Lettere and mine; the≈øe are to enforme you that we have beene in very hot and ≈øharpe ≈øervice, making attempt to gaine a bridge to Shrewsbury which we did gaine and made the enemie fly in halfe an howers hot ≈øervice. My Lord him≈øelfe lead on galantly in the forlorne hope, having not patience till the bridge could bee let downe, we all in the forlorne hope crouded through the R ‚Ä¢ ver to our hor≈øe skirts, wee only had one man fell over there was drownd, ≈øo we pur≈øued and tooke Major Fi≈øher Major Manly, and many other pri≈øoners, they i≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ed out of Shrewsbury and fought with us, we beat them in, and finding our ≈øelves to few to be≈øiege it, we in the night retreated
and are now this day upon news received marching for York. The news to us is this enclo≈øed, for I now am in ha≈øte.

closer.dateline: Dated at Weme, newly come from Shrewsbury. July 9. 1644.

body.p:
I Ble≈ø≈øe God I yet live to prai≈øe him for his renewed mer
‚Ä¢ e to me and our Armie, and to write to you our condition, & that you may have a true te≈øt, my General hates idlenes, I mu≈øt tell you he ets us not re≈øt night nor day, but upon on de≈øigne or other wee vvere this day ≈øevennight at Mauche≈øter, then hurried wee to Knotsford, North vvitch, and to O≈øvve≈øtrie to relieve that: at vvhich place and in that ≈øervice, Sir Thomas Middletons Troope and mine had the brunt of the ≈øervice, and came off vvith honour: they tired our vvith often charging. Sir Thomas brought up other hor≈øe to relieve them: who fell on gallantly, and did good ≈øervice: and pur≈øued the Enemy neere Shrewsbury, and took many pri≈øoners of qualitie, the Lord Newports ≈øonne a Parliament man, Marrow hardly e≈øcaped.

The very next day my Lord Generall ≈øent Captaine Rent to give Orders for all hor≈øe and foot to quarter on and about Sutton on the Hill, in the way to Shrewsbury, early next morning vve marched tovvards Mansford Bridge vvhere the Enemy kept Garri≈øon: and a drawbridge over the Severne: our men fell on gallantly, and my Lord him≈øelfe appeared in the Van of the Forlorn Hope for their encouragement, which cau≈øed them to ≈øtir bravely, and to ≈øtrive to adventure beyond expre≈ø≈øion, to gain the pa≈ø≈øage in a quarter of an houres time the Enemy fled: upon which my Lord ≈øent Cap. Keme to call the Forlorn Hope of Hor≈øe, and after other hor≈øe which hee did, and wee came ≈øo ha≈øtily on, that one Captaine Shipply a
gallant man, not having patience to ≈øtay till the draw bridge was let down, ventured over the River after him, rent the Forlorn Hope, In pur≈øuit, and my Lord was in the mid≈øt of them, and only one man next me, and not far from my Lord, fell into a hole of the River, hardly e≈øcaped drowned.

Thus wee got out, and by this time the bridge was downe, our Army crowding over. I mean the hor≈øe out of Captaine Kemes Troop came in at a hou≈øe over the bridge where they kept the Court of Guard, and tooke a Lievtenant Colonels Colours which he gave his Captaine to pre≈øent to my Lord, but we followed the pur≈øuit, and between the Bridge and the Heath we tooke mo≈øt of the men, and had wee not hallowed for all our hor≈øe to come up we had entred Shrewshury, with the enemie, many of their hor≈øe and foot quartering our of Towne which wee lighted on ≈øome of Marrows Dragoones: We drew up till our armie came up on a Heath on this ≈øide Shrevvsbury a mile, the enemy came in parties up Ambu≈øcadoes, the lanes vve beat them from them. Colonell Booth lead his Regiment of Foot on him≈øelfe valiantly: and my Lords ovvne hor≈øe, his life Guard commanded by Captaine Tovy a gallant man pur≈øued to pi≈øtoll ≈øhot of the Workes: Marrow came out, and Major Manly, and fought vvith us; and there vvas a hot bout for tvvo hours and above: Wee tooke Major Fi≈øher, Major Manly Governour of Bangor, and divers other Officers and Souldiers.
We made good the ground within Musket ≈øhot of their Works till night: then ≈øeeing our little Armie was not able to ≈øit downe before it: my Lord drew off and vvee retreated that night to the Heath.

A mile off and the whole Army quartered in the fields, the hor≈øe, foot and carriages on the Heath. Next morning wee matched away upon advice of the Councell of Warre to Weme: where we quartered all night, being Friday. Saturday
we marched to Whitchurch: On the Lords Day morning, my Lord had Captain Keme to preach, which he did and after dinner gave him order to order a Randevouz at Normans Heath which was done: where my Lord further declared his intentions to ≈øend the Ca≈øhire Gentlemen, and on his march to ob≈øerve the commands of the Committees of both Kingdome to ≈øecure Lanca≈øhire and Che≈øhire to waite on P. Rupert, to call in at Cholmley hou≈øe, a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon of the Enemies: My Lord with his owne Troop and Colonell Bartons; and Ma or Burtons, and Captaine Kemes, and Captaine Farmers, and ≈øome two Troopes more marched to view the ground, we came to it, and found it full of difficultie, unle≈ø≈øe we ≈øpent time on it. Yee my Lord ≈øent them a ≈øummons by a Trumpet, which was to tell them, hee required in his pa≈ø≈øage to have quater in the hou≈øe for his army, for the u≈øe of King and Parliament; the Enemy ≈øcorned to an≈øwer, but ≈øhot at the Trumpeter: upon which, my Lord gave order to draw up his Cannon, and early ≈øaluted them: and finding them to cake little effect, re≈øolved to ≈øtorme it; upon information it was ≈øurrounded with a ≈ømall ditch only; But the Che≈øhire men that knew it was a Moat deep and broad: were ≈øomwhat backward to adventure their men: My Lord told th ‚Ä¢ m his Honour was ingaged in it; what hee did was in affection to expre≈ø≈øe his affections to them. And if they would not goe on, he would go on with his Stafford foot him ≈øelf; Major Low then a gallant man lately come out of pri≈øon: hearing it went to ≈øome of the Che≈øhire Officers, and told them what my. Lord ≈øaid: upon which they drew forth a 100 out of a Regiment. So Major Pinkny a mo≈øt valiant hone≈øt Gentleman led on the Stafford foot, who had the brunt of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe: Lievtenant Colonell _____ the Che≈øhire, and Major Croxon, and after the ≈øignall of two piece of Ordnance, fell on to ≈øtorm it, and ≈øuch a ≈øtorm, as I never heard the like but at Ba≈øing,
in half an houres time, they within cried quarter; but by rea≈øon of hollowing, and Drummes and Trumpets they could not be heard: at la≈øt our men entred the draw bridge, and took it.

In which entry Major Barton Captain Tory, and Captain Hitchcock, and Captain Harford did good ≈øervice, facing their hor≈øes, and in which enery in the croud, I had like to have lo≈øt my life, or taken the more when we came in four men were ≈øo mercifull to give them their lives, till we heard brave Major P nkney was ≈ølain, ≈øhot in the belly and in the armes by two flags, who is much lamented, Captain Keme is to p ‚Ä¢ each, this evening at his funera, he was my Lords Major of St ‚Ä¢ fford foote, under Colonel Rudgeley. In the hou≈øe was little riches only ≈øome good hor≈øes, 2 barrels of powder, and ≈øtore of bullets: what there was the Souldiers had, and arms about a 100 pri≈øoners, Lievtenant Colonell Horton, and others, 66 in all. My Lord gave them to the Che≈øhire Gentlemen, and the hor≈øe to Reare Garri≈øon. It is a place if you ≈øee it miraculon≈øly gained by Gods free love, with lo≈ø≈øe but of five men, and 6 wounded, This night we came to Namptwitch, to morrow is a day of Thankigiving to God for our ≈øelves, and the great bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of York. I have ≈øent you the Cavaliers Prote≈øtation I found in the hou≈øe. My love to all our friends. Pray and prai≈øe God, I re≈øt yours.

div.head: A PROTESTATION, Confirmed by Oath, taken by the Major and the Loyally affected in the City of Chester, for the Defence of that City, again≈øt this pre≈øent Rebellion. 1644.
div.p: I A. B. Dofreely, and from my heart vow and Prote≈øt, in the pre≈øence of Alm ghty God, that I will, with my life and utmo≈øt Power, maintain and defend this hou≈øe of Chulmley, again≈øt al Forces rai≈øed, or to be rai≈øed without his Maje≈øties expre≈øse con≈øent upon any pretence what≈øoever; and particularly again≈øt the Forces now under the Conduct of the Earle of E≈ø≈øex and Sir William Brewerton, and all Forces which do or ≈øhall adhere unto them, or either of them or their Party. And I will neither directly, nor indirectly give or ≈øuffer to be given, any Intelligence to the ≈øaid Earl of E≈ø≈øex, or Sir William Brewerton, or any their Forces or Adherents in Prejudice of this hou≈øe, or the forces within the ≈øame; but will di≈øcover to the Governour of the Forces within the ≈øaid hou≈øe, all ≈øuch Plots and De≈øignes as I ≈øhall know to be against the ≈øaid hou≈øe. And this I vow and Prote≈øt, without any Equivocation or mentall Re≈øervation; Beleeving that I cannot he Ab≈øolved from this my Vow and Prote≈øtation; And wi≈øhing no ble≈ø≈øing from Almighty God if I do not performe the ≈øame; So help me God, And by the Contents of this Book.
